job_title: Staff RN in Newport Beach, CA
pros: Good benefits, adequate pay and state of the art facility; Profitable business
cons: Leadership and management are deceptive in their presentation. They present as accountable and open to employee input. However, punitive actions are directed towards employees who present issues that require change. While Hoag presents with state of art facilities and maintains an image as an exemplary healthcare provider, the RN staffing is consistently out of ratio which results in a lack of sufficient breaks outside of the legal guidelines. Yet, staff is threatened with disciplinary actions all the way to termination for any overtime accrued including 1 or 2 minutes and missed time keeping events. Leadership seems to believe that it is acceptable for the staff to work so hard to meet their expectations of service while not providing adequate staffing. The hospital also will not hire applicants who have worked at a union hospital to minimize any influence of unionizing nursing and keep tight control on the staff. The hospital declines to use travelers while remaining critically understaffed in specific areas of the hospital. It's time Hoag came to the realization that authoritative and rigid leadership does not work it only burns out the employees.

job_title: Clinical Coordinator in Newport Beach, CA
pros:
Speaking from only my position in Admin because I know other departments and areas aren’t like this but…
- My team is awesome and professional and we work together with no drama or toxicity.
- Job isn’t as difficult as difficult as the job posting stated and I tend to have a lot of free time to do whatever else I see fit.
- My supervisor also does not micromanage me so it’s easier to get things done and adjust based on feedback.
- Health insurance is awesome and under the Hoag medical group.
- 401k matching even without contribution.
- 20% Discount on food in cafe/cafeteria.
cons:
- Parking structure in Newport Beach is a nightmare. If you get there at a wrong time, good luck getting parking after cruising through all 4 levels consistently for 45 min. You will end up having to park down in sunset lot which is a 10-15 min walk uphill to the main hospital or wait for the shuttle.
- PTO accrual is basically a day a paycheck which sounds awesome but you have to use your PTO for holidays that other companies already cover. I ended up just working holidays to save my PTO for vacations.
- This year in 2022 they did a higher merit increase but excluded bonuses. I’m sure this is great for many but I was really looking forward to a bonus this year as I am planning on moving to a new job in a new location in a few months. The benefit mostly screwed me but is a pro if you are staying long term.
-Salary wasn’t the greatest and my role expanded to me doing numerous things that isn’t reflected in my pay. I just ended up not doing that much work because I was burned out with no incentive.

job_title: Pharmacy Technician in Fountain Valley, CA
pros: Staff outside the pharmacy are friendlier than my own department. Management is hands off but that can be good and bad. Benefits are good and management are willing to work around your schedule.
cons:
Management is hands off and so a lot of technicians take advantage of it. Some techs take long breaks and don’t do their jobs. The good techs cover for the slackers but don’t get the recognition. There’s a mean girl culture on the tech side that needs to be dealt with. It’s just not a friendly environment. Lots of gossip and high school drama. 

Pharmacists are in it for themselves. After management leaves, most pharmacists won’t even check stat IV’s for the patients even after letting them know it’s stat. They don’t cover each other for breaks, leaving medications to be piled up. It’s a culture that needs to be fixed.

I can say that I love management not only as my leaders, but as individuals.
cons: Health care changes are causing crunches and putting pressure on hospitals. Management is doing the best they can with the changes we are facing.  It's a difficult time, but not the worst I have seen in my career.  The future is slightly uncertain; unfortunately we don't have a crystal ball.

job_title: Respiratory Care Practitioner in Newport Beach, CA

A clinical ladder can be specific: bronchoscopy, training in NICU, PFT's, ABG coordinator, etc.
cons: Hoag  is not known for being lenient with their employees.  They follow a strict guidelines and are not afraid to enforce their policy and procedures with corrective actions.  Hoag expects a lot out of their employees: 35-40 points per shift - starting.  In addition to "special projects" that are expected of you to complete as a goal on your review.  Moral wavers between low and medium-low as a whole.

review_title: Nursing students: This is a great place to start
job_title: Supervisor in Newport Beach, CA
pros:
Nursing Students: You receive tuition reimbursement  for your  RN, BSN, MSN licenses, and/or practitioner. Once you enter the program you have a 90% chance of being offered a PCA position.  There are Cons to this though.

The CEO Robert Braithwaite: began his career at Hoag cleaning equipment and delivering supplies, an honest start from the bottom. Since he started at an entry level position he gives his employees opportunities to grow by using leadership programs by Franklin Covey. He rose from a technician to CEO by educating himself and using consultants to keep up to date with candidates to stand apart from the rest. Hoag Newport offers the best benefits because of the size and resources from donors, start here and enjoy the spoils.

Flexible schedule: Monthly schedule, Charge RN's or Directors make schedule and you can switch ask for days in a row and they realize nursing is #1

Hoag Irvine: is great if you want to learn to multi-task and work more often then you Newport beach counterparts. 

Hoag Newport: constantly expanding, pouring funds and resources into improvements and making the facilities above and beyond expectations.
cons:
Nursing Students: You are offered very low once you attain your RN because they have invested in you. (Ex. as a PCA you made 15 hourly, now when you become a RN you are offered 26-30 hourly). RN's with the same experience and education hired from the outside can receive 30-35 hourly. This is huge when annual reviews which are 3% (there is no wiggle room even if you are the hospitals top performer...3% set by compensation dept.) but you decide if the opportunity is worth the sacrifice. 

CEO: Has his RN license but does not openly share this at all.

Flexible Schedule: People within the departments may not always play by the rules and take frequent vacations and leave the rest of the team demoralized by the added stress of their absence. On the other hand you can do the same and care less about others with no penalty.

Hoag Irvine: A handful of Newport employees views Irvine as "Those who couldn't cut it at Newport". This may hold some truth, If you work at Irvine or float to Irvine you will eventually hear "We do things differently here at Hoag Irvine". Which they do, you decide if its more efficient. They work hard in each department and work with a skeleton crew a majority of the time. There are no directors, only managers.

Directors, Vice Presidents, Managers, Executive Directors: There are a large number of directors and vice presidents. Does a director manage managers? not necessarily, you can have a director with 5-7 subordinates while at hoag Irvine you can have a managers who manages 30 employees and not have  equal pay or title. 

Hoag Newport beach: The ER has held patients above the nurse to patient limit in the past, this is in place in California to protect patients, How? They will treat patients and enter the patient into the system later to make it appear as though that patient arrived later, why? Because the hospital could be audited and fined for placing patients at risk. Advice: Always document everything and note times, protect patients and your sanity and blow the whistle if you are asked to do this by your charge RN.

Closed positions: Either due to death, quitting or termination positions are a struggle to fill or reopen leaving you with less help when either occurs.  

Sexual Harassment: Some transport staff and EVS can be inappropriate. If this occurs place a We Care onlinr and have that pervert removed.

HOI: This is the Cash cow of Hoag. Anything the physicians want, Hoag will bend over backwards to get. They do not play by the same rules over there at HOI. Imagine Kaiser Permanente operating inside a non-profit using all its resources...this describes HOI best.  

Transparency: No way of knowing what is the starting, mid and top end of a position.

review_title: You almost get what you put into it!
job_title: Admitting Representative III in Newport Beach, CA
pros: Amazing Values. Good synergy with all working staff. Awesome benefits and educational reimbursement.
cons:
Capped at 5 % annual pay raise. No one has ever actually obtained a 5% increase, they only deliver 3% no matter how hard you work to achieve it. There isn't much incentive to stay. Good luck with talking to upper management. As long as their charts & graphs look good to their higher ups and you do the job well, they will steer clear of you.

On another note: Occasionally, the medical staff will forget their job and have demands not related to admissions which we fulfill with a smile. (It's easy to be pointed out a scapegoat when you are not a needle pusher.) Med staff will give most impulsive reactions to anything they do not understand or if something simply is misplaced so our communication is always on the high road. Respect is created not earned in this environment so forcefully you will exude professionalism while backhanding and caressing in the same motion to those who swell their chests and stare down their nose at you. job_title: in Newport Beach, CA
pros: This hospital is located close to the beach, so it does have ocean views.  This is the only positive thing I can say about this hospital.
cons:
HOSTILE WORK ENVIRONMENT!!!  I have worked in hospitals for 19 years.  Hoag is by far the worst place I have EVER worked for.  Shortly after beginning employment with Hoag, I unfortunately got diagnosed with a rare nerve disease (CRPS).  I initially took an intermittent leave of absence because I wanted to work as much as I could still.  I began to be harassed and accused of "faking" my disease.  When I told my Lead about it, his reply was "Well, what do you expect, for them (the subordinates) to be happy with you?".  I was SO let down and shocked.  I told my manager about it, and nothing changed.  My picture got de-faced twice (which I will post on here) and when I reported it to Human Resources, their answer was to just put a glass enclosure over the picture so no one could get to it.  I asked "But, are you going to actually take care of the root of the problem and not just cover my picture and sweep it under the rug?".  Human Resources and managements answer was "yes".  Unbelievable.  So I replied by saying "But that doesn't take care of the problem, I am being harassed"  I explained that I felt the proper protocol should be for all laboratory personnel to have to review and sign the 'Code of Conduct' again.  They finally did, but Human Resources took credit for the idea later.  Eventually, I started looking for a different job because the harassment and stress became so bad, and stress plays a direct role with my disease and aggravates it.  So, I went to an interview and to my disbelief, the Manager I interviewed with had somehow spoke with someone at Hoag and that someone at Hoag had given all of my PRIVATE medical information to this manager at the nearby hospital I interviewed at!  I was mortified and in actual disbelief and found myself trying to explain my disease in this awkward interview.  This is a major HIPAA violation!  
To top this all off-  my mother & father-in-law are benefactors at Hoag, meaning they have donated enough money to have a donor's plaque on the wall at Hoag Hospital.  Obviously, my family will NOT be donating anymore money to Hoag.  WORST EXPERIENCE EVER!!!
